title: 105_hr2408
content: The "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" aims to improve academic and social outcomes for students by offering productive activities during after school hours. The findings in the "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" highlight the increased social risks faced by today's youth, including spending more unsupervised time alone and being at higher risk of violence during after school hours. The goals of the Act include increasing academic success, improving various skills, promoting safe environments, preparing for workforce participation, and providing alternatives to negative activities. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "school" refers to public kindergarten, elementary, or secondary schools. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. SEC. 6. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Secretary can award grants to schools for carrying out activities in section 7(a). SEC. 7. AUTHORIZED ACTIVITIES; REQUIREMENTS. Each school receiving a grant under this Act must conduct mentoring programs, academic assistance, recreational activities, and technology training. Additionally, schools may choose to implement drug, alcohol, and gang prevention activities, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation activities. A school must provide activities such as mentoring programs, academic assistance, recreational activities, technology training, drug, alcohol, and gang prevention, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation after regular school hours. The activities should reflect the specific needs of the population and be carried out in a designated school building or public facility. In carrying out activities after school hours, schools are encouraged to seek volunteers from the business and academic communities, request computer equipment donations, and collaborate with state and local park agencies to avoid duplication of activities. SEC. 8. APPLICATIONS. Each school seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary, detailing how the goals of the Act will be met, showing collaborative efforts, describing the administration of activities, and explaining the utilization of resources. The application for the grant must detail how the activities will be administered, demonstrate collaboration with other programs, describe funding sources, and include a plan for obtaining non-Federal funding. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1998 to 2002.
